person_101.name: Ambrosio
person_101.description: A fictional character in Humphry Davy's Consolations in Travel (1830).

person_108.name: Onuphrio
person_108.description: Onuphiro is the name of a fictional character in the dialogues of Davy's Consolations in Travel. The anglicized version of the name is Humphry.

person_102.name: Philalethes
person_102.description: A fictional character in Humphry Davy's Consolations in Travel (1830).

person_935.name: JakobBÃ¶hme
person_935.description: (Jacob Behman), a German philosopher, Christian mystic, and Lutheran Protestant theologian.

person_114.name: Muhammad
person_114.description: The Holy Prophet and founder of Islam.

person_951.name: JesusChrist
person_951.description: The central figure of Christianity; a first-century Jewish preacher and religious leader.

person_955.name: Constantine
person_955.description: Roman emperor from AD 306 to 337; he patronised Christianity and was converted to it on his deathbed.

person_956.name: Cain
person_956.description: A biblical figure in the Book of Genesis. He is the firstborn son of Adam and Eve and brother of Abel.

person_036.name: IsaacNewton
person_036.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

person_078.name: JohnLocke
person_078.description: English philosopher and physician, widely regarded as one of the most influential of early Enlightenment thinkers. FRSL.

person_018.name: DavidHartley
person_018.description: Associationist, whose work argued that the vibrations of nerves created sensation. FRSL.

person_115.name: Moses
person_115.description: According to the Old Testament Hebrew prophet who is considered the most important prophet in Judaism and one of the most important prophets in Christianity and other religions.

place_704.name: Bay of Naples
place_704.description: The Bay (or Gulf) of Naples is located on the south-western coast of Italy, with Naples to the north, Vesuvius to the east, and the Sorrento Peninsula to the south.

place_199.name: The Colosseum
place_199.description: The Colosseum, the largest amphitheatre ever built, is located in the centre of Rome. Now a ruin, its construction began 2,000 years ago.

place_156.name: Naples
place_156.description: Naples is the regional capital of Campania in Italy. It is located beneath the volcano, Vesuvius.

place_1169.name: Mount Somma
place_1169.description: A mountain located in the Province of Naples, in the Campania region of southern Italy. It has a collapsed caldera of an older volcano, with Mount Vesuvius rising up from the center.

place_413.name: Portici
place_413.description: A town and comune of the Metropolitan City of Naples in Italy

place_714.name: Herculaneum
place_714.description: Herculaneum was an ancient Roman town, located in the modern-day comune of Ercolano, Campania, Italy.

place_685.name: New Holland
place_685.description: New Holland was the name first given to Australia by the Dutch seafarer, Abel Tasman.

place_1160.name: New Zealand
place_1160.description: An island country in the southwestern Pacific Ocean.

place_1162.name: northern coast of Africa
place_1162.description: The coastal region of North Africa bounded by Egypt (east), by the Atlantic (west), by the Sahara (south), and by the Mediterranean Sea (north), and now comprising Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia, and Libya.

place_173.name: Jerusalem
place_173.description: Jerusalem is an ancient city in West Asia, on a plateau in the Judaean Mountains between the Mediterranean and the Dead Sea.

place_873.name: Iran
place_873.description: Iran, also known as Persia and officially the Islamic Republic of Iran, is a country located at the crossroads of West, Central and South Asia.

place_1186.name: Judaea
place_1186.description: The southernmost of the three traditional divisions of ancient Palestine; there are political and religious disputes over what to call this land today.

place_1191.name: Mediterranean Sea
place_1191.description: Connected to the Atlantic Ocean and almost completely surrounded by land.

place_940.name: Orkney
place_940.description: An archipelago off the northeastern coast of Scotland.

place_222.name: Africa
place_222.description: The world's second-largest and second-most populous continent.

place_180.name: Paestum
place_180.description: Paestum was an ancient Greek city on the coast of southern Italy.

place_1032.name: Eboli
place_1032.description: An Italian town in the province of Salerno.

place_711.name: Salerno
place_711.description: City in south-western Italy, located on the Gulf of Salerno. Salerno is the capital city of the Italian province also named Salerno, in the Campania region of Italy.

place_1202.name: Sorrento
place_1202.description: A coastal town in southwestern Italy.

place_1142.name: Tyrrhenian Sea
place_1142.description: Part of the Mediterranean Sea off the western coast of Italy.

place_184.name: Mount Etna
place_184.description: Mount Etna, or simply Etna, is an active stratovolcano on the east coast of Sicily, Italy.

place_1174.name: Stromboli
place_1174.description: an island in the Tyrrhenian Sea, off the north coast of Sicily, containing Mount Stromboli, one of the four active volcanoes in Italy. It is one of the seven Aeolian Islands, a volcanic arc north of Sicily.

place_408.name: Lipari
place_408.description: A commune including six of seven islands of the Aeolian Islands located in the Tyrrhenian Sea off the northern coast of Sicily in southern Italy.

place_1204.name: Po Valley
place_1204.description: A vast plain area in Northern Italy, featuring the Po River.

place_247.name: Alps
place_247.description: The Alps are the highest and most extensive mountain range that lies entirely in Europe. They are located in eight European countries.

place_848.name: Velino
place_848.description: A river in central Italy, a tributary of the Nera.

place_565.name: Terni
place_565.description: Terni is a city in the southern portion of the region of Umbria in central Italy.

place_527.name: Aniene River
place_527.description: The Aniene is a river rising in the Apennines and flowing west to join the Tiber in northern Rome. It is famous for the Tivoli waterfall.

place_1205.name: Aniene
place_1205.description: A river that originates in the Appenines in Italy, formerly called the Teverone.

place_529.name: Tivoli, Lazio
place_529.description: Tivoli is a town north east of Rome and known for the waterfall on the Aniene River.

place_612.name: Campagna
place_612.description: The Roman Campagna is an area of low-lying countryside surrounding Rome, where both the Tiber and Aniene Rivers flow.

place_179.name: Albulae Aquae
place_179.description: White Waters'; a group of springs to the west of Tivolo, Italy, and location of an ancient Roman settlement.

place_528.name: Solfatara Caldera
place_528.description: Solfatara di Pozzuoli is a volcanic crater near Naples. Though a dormant volcano, it emits jets of steam and sulphurous fumes.

otherwork_037.name: Consolations in Travel, or the Last Days of Philosopher
otherwork_037.author: Humphry Davy

otherwork_038.name: Consolations in Travel, or the Last Days of Philosopher
otherwork_038.author: Humphry Davy
